properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, heavy at times, is expected to develop Thursday and continue into Friday. The frozen ground will have a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Rain is forecast to develop over the region Thursday morning. Rain is then expected to continue through Thursday night and likely be heavy at times. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are expected with this event. By Friday morning, Christmas Day, the rain is expected to change to scattered flurries or periods of snow as temperatures drop to below the freezing mark. A few centimetres of snow will be possible. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T14:37:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T22:37:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1078486105.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A frontal system will stall over the region bringing periods of heavy snow on Thursday. Snow will develop this evening and intensify On Thursday. Snow is expected to continue into Thursday evening before tapering off. In addition, Highway 97 - Pine Pass will likely see heavy snow develop tonight and continue through to Thursday evening. Gusty winds will also lead to drifting snow and reduced visibilities at times. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A significant winter storm is expected tonight and Thursday. Snow, at times heavy, will continue tonight and gradually taper to flurries Thursday night. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are expected by Friday morning. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Driving conditions will continue to deteriorate today as the snow continues. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:22:35-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Bitterly cold wind chills of minus 45 will develop overnight and then ease Thursday morning. A warm front will pass through the province Christmas eve which will bring some snow and then above normal temperatures for Christmas day. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T10:14:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T21:27:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3770670548.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold north wind will bring extreme wind chills of minus 40 to much of southern Manitoba overnight and into Thursday morning. A warm front will pass through the province Christmas eve which will bring above normal temperatures for Christmas day. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:26:57-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected tonight. This Snowfall Warning replaces the Special Weather Statement that was previously in effect. Snow will continue tonight into Thursday, easing to flurries by Thursday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by Thursday evening, The highest snowfall amounts are expected to be north and northwest of the town of Wawa. For Wawa and areas near the shoreline of Lake Superior, snow amount may be less than 10 cm due to a mix of wet snow and rain that will persist for most of the night before transitioning to snow early Thursday morning. Brisk northerly winds with gusts of 50 to 60 km/h are expected late this evening into Thursday that may result in localized blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T14:23:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T22:23:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4220020984.2020
Area: Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts of 40 to 65 cm are expected by Friday morning. A frontal system over the North Coast will continue to give snow to inland sections tonight through Thursday. Over North Coast - inland including Stewart, approximately 20 to 30 cm has already fallen today with a further 25 cm expected tonight before easing Thursday morning. Over North Coast - inland including Terrace and Kitimat, approximately 5 to 10 cm fell today before the snow became mixed with rain, but will change back to snow at times heavy tonight and continue through Thursday. Further snowfall amounts of 45 to 55 cm can be expected by Friday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T15:47:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T23:47:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0599150664.2020

Southeasterly winds of 90 km/h are possible, especially over the more exposed coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Between 25 and 60 millimetres of rain is expected with up to 100 millimetres possible locally in the Sept-Îles region. On Christmas Eve, a strong southerly flow will bring mild temperatures, sustained winds and rain to the entire province. These conditions will progress from west to east through the 25th of December. The heavy rain may cause flash floods and pooling on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible on Christmas Day. Rain is forecast to begin tonight ahead of an approaching low pressure system. This rain will then transition to light snow Thursday afternoon or Thursday evening. A few centimetres of snowfall accumulation will be possible by Christmas morning. Then Christmas Day, a new low pressure system is forecast to track northward towards the area, spreading heavy snow ahead of it. Snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 15 cm range will be possible, before a potential transition to ice pellets or freezing rain. Several hours of ice pellets or freezing rain may occur before the precipitation gradually tapers off Friday night. Snowfall Warnings may be required at a later time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:44:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T21:44:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0873975288.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant winter storm continues tonight. Snow at times heavy, will continue tonight and gradually taper to flurries from west to east on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Total accumulations of up to 50 cm locally are possible. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Hazardous winter driving conditions are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:16:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T21:16:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1010979623.2020

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By The Village Of Richmound
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Village of Richmound. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Village of Richmound water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A frontal system will bring heavy snow to sections of the Dempster Highway near the Richardson Mountains tonight. Snow will combine with gusty southwesterly winds to produce local areas of blowing snow tonight and Thursday morning. Snow will taper off Thursday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T15:52:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T23:52:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1785422891.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected Thursday into Friday morning. There is also the risk of freezing rain or ice pellets. Rain is forecast to develop over the region Thursday morning. This rain is then expected to continue through Thursday night. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 40 mm are possible with this event. By Friday morning, Christmas Day, the rain is expected to change to scattered flurries or periods of snow as temperatures drop to below the freezing mark. There may also be a period of freezing rain or ice pellets during the transition. A few centimetres of snow will be possible. This rain is associated with a strong low pressure system that will approach the area from the south Thursday. There remains some uncertainty as to the exact track of this low pressure system. Areas may transition to snow earlier than currently forecast, changing associated precipitation amounts. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is a possible as the frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb rainfall. Rainfall Warnings may be required as the event draws closer. Some regions may require freezing rain warnings during the storm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T14:38:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T22:38:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3823661208.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues over northern sections tonight. Snow at times heavy will continue for areas north of Missinaibi lake tonight and gradually taper to flurries from west to east on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Locally higher amounts up to 25 cm are possible for areas closer to Kapuskasing and Hornepayne. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Areas south of Missinaibi lake, which include the city of Chapleau and Sultan, will not receive as much snow. These areas will receive rain showers for much of the night and transition to snow early Thursday morning. The snow should taper to flurries Thursday afternoon. A total snowfall amount of up to 5 cm is possible for these areas on Thursday. Consider post-poning non essential travel in the northern areas until conditions improve. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:38:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T21:38:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1490723581.2020
Area: Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T22:36:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2031237401.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Strong winds with gusts to 90 km/h, will combine with the freshly fallen snow to create poor visibility in blowing snow through most of the night. The visibility should improve Thursday morning as winds weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant winter storm continues tonight. Snow, at times heavy, will continue tonight and gradually taper to flurries Thursday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. The stretch of highway 11 from Hearst northwest to Calstock may experience higher snowfall rates than areas further southeast that may significantly impact travel. In the southeastern sections, from Moonbeam to Smooth Rock Falls, snow may mix with rain beginning this evening as temperatures rise above the freezing mark. The snow mixed with rain will then transition to snow early Thursday morning and taper to flurries Thursday afternoon. Brisk northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T13:19:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T21:19:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1961030373.2020
Area: Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A frontal system will stall over the region bringing periods of heavy snow on Thursday. Snow will develop this evening and intensify On Thursday. Snow is expected to continue into Thursday evening before tapering off. In addition, Highway 97 - Pine Pass will likely see heavy snow develop tonight and continue through to Thursday evening. Gusty winds will also lead to drifting snow and reduced visibilities at times. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T18:00:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-24T02:00:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2151440683.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight through Thursday. Snow will continue tonight into Thursday, gradually easing to flurries by Thursday evening. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are expected by Friday morning. For areas north of the Kapiskau River, total snowfall accumulations of 15 cm are expected as the band of heavy snow will remain further south. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, wet and windy conditions expected for Friday and Saturday. Total rainfall: 20-50 mm. Locally 60 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: 70-90 km/h with the highest gusts along the Atlantic Coast. Storm surge: higher than normal water levels are expected from Lunenburg east to Sheet Harbour near 4 am AST on Saturday. Significant coastal flooding is not expected at this point, but if the storm intensifies there may be minor flooding. Wave heights: up to 6 metres, breaking higher upon approaching the shore. For the Atlantic Coast beginning early Saturday and persisting most of the day. Locations: Western Nova Scotia and Cumberland County. Time span: Light rain will begin on Friday, intensifying on Saturday, and move east of the Province overnight into Sunday. High tide: near 4 am AST on Saturday. Remarks: A low pressure system approaching from the Great Lakes will bring rain to the province beginning on Friday and intensifying overnight into Saturday. Winds will intensify ahead of this system with winds nearing warning levels along the Atlantic Coast. Conditions will improve Saturday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T18:26:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-24T02:26:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0477306478.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass
